column37: Notes/DataSource: Black&Veatch 2012 and CEC COG Model Version 2.02-4-5-10 unless otherwise stated
Same as new CCGT, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as CCGT_CCS; 75% capital cost and fixed cost
B&V; the lifetime, construction time, construction cost breakdown, and outage rates are the same as CCGT
Same as new CCGT, but with 2008 capital cost
Same as existing CCGT, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as gas combustion turbines, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as gas combustion turbine CCS; 75% capital cost and fixed cost

We assumed that the capital cost and fixed cost for adding a CCS system increase by the same amount (per W) as for CCGT; we assumed CCS combustion turbine heat rate increases by the same percentage relative to non-CCS combustion turbines as CCS to non-CCS CCGT heat rates; we also assume that there's an adder per MWh for variable costs -- we assume that the difference in variable cost scales with the difference in heat rates (varO&M scales with fuel use)
Same as new Combustion Turbine, but with 2008 capital cost
Same as existing combustion turbines, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as Gas_Internal_Combustion_Engine_Cogen_EP (which already includes the 75% of capital and fixed costs)
Same as Gas_Combustion_Turbine_Cogen_CCS
Same as existing gas combustion turbines
Same as existing Gas Internal Combustion Engine, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as existing gas steam turbines, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Capital and fixed cost equal to 75% of Gas_Steam_Turbine_EP + difference between CCGT_CCS and CCGT, other flags like Gas_Steam_Turbine_Cogen (except ccs)
OGS (Oil Gas Steam) Tidball et al (NREL cost comparison), outage rates from 2006-2010 NERC Generating Availability Report, construction schedule like Coal Steam Turbine
Same as existing gas steam turbines, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as existing Gas Combustion Turbine
Same as existing Gas Combustion Turbine
Same as new coal steam turbines, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Capital and fixed cost equal to 75% of Coal_Steam_Turbine_CCS
same as coal steam turbine, but using 2008 costs
Same as existing coal steam turbines, 75% capital cost and fixed cost

We assumed that the capital cost and fixed cost for adding a CCS system increase by the same amount (per W) as for Coal IGCC;  we assumed CCS biomass IGCC heat rate increases by the same percentage relative to non-CCS biomass IGCC as CCS to non-CCS coal IGCC heat rates; we also assume that there's an adder per MWh for variable costs -- we assume that the difference in variable cost scales with the difference in heat rates
Same as biomass steam turbine EP, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as Biomass_IGCC for costs (heat rate derived upstream from here)
Same as non-ccs version, except for 75% of capex and fixed O&M costs
NREL REF/EPRI McGowin 2007
Took CCGT_CCS to CCGT ratio for heat rate; everything else same as Bio_Gas
Same as new Biogas, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Heat rate derived in MySQL; same as non-CCS equivalent otherwise
Same as new Biogas
Same as new Biogas, 75% capital cost and fixed cost

Everything but costs same as gas steam turbine; captial and fixed costs are assumed to be the gas steam turbine cost plus the difference between biogas and gas combustion turbine, except for VarO&M, which was taken from bio solid steam turbine EP
Same as biomass steam turbine, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as biomass steam turbine, 75% capital cost and fixed cost
Same as non-CCS version; heat rate derived in MySQL
Same as new wind except for a generic connect cost
Fixed-Bottom costs used… should split fixed and floating at some point

0.74 taken as efficiency because it's more representative of existing plants rather than new builds.  Also, if you change the efficiency value here, make sure to also change it when calculating hydro monthly flows

$1,200,000 taken as capital cost in 2010 rather than 2004 based on conversation with Hernandez, also The storage efficiency of the the storage phase of compressed air energy storage from Samir Succar and Robert H. Williams: Compressed Air Energy Storage: Theory, Resources, And Applications For Wind Power, p. 39
